data.text: Contents
Care of patients with dementia / MSEPO-20253 /
Page  of
Introduction

Dementia is a syndrome – usually of a chronic or progressive nature – in which there is deterioration in cognitive function (i.e. the ability to process thought) beyond what might be expected from normal ageing. It affects memory, thinking, orientation, comprehension, calculation, learning capacity, language, and judgement. Consciousness is not affected. The impairment in cognitive function is commonly accompanied, and occasionally preceded, by deterioration in emotional control, social behavior, or motivation (World Health Organisation, 2019). It is a life-limiting disease.
One in six people over the age of  will have dementia (Alzheimer's Society, 2019). Dementia is not a normal symptom of ageing.

Being in hospital can be an unsettling and disorientating experience for anyone. For a person with dementia the effects may be much worse. There is growing evidence that when compared to patients without dementia, patients with dementia in hospital are more likely to:
Experience poor nutrition and poor hydration;
Develop delirium;
Receive inadequate pain control;
Experience extended hospital stays;
Move from hospital into long term care.

At least 25% of hospital beds are occupied by people with dementia. On average, people with dementia in hospital stay more than twice as long as other patients aged over  (Alzheimer's Society, 2016). People with dementia are usually dependant on staff having the skills and knowledge to meet their needs effectively and ensure the patient's experience is less stressful and their inpatient stay is no longer than necessary.
Scope
The purpose of this policy is to provide all clinical staff, paid, voluntary or contracted with guidance to assist them in meeting the specific needs of patients with dementia.

To ensure compliance with national guidance, specifically: the National Dementia Strategy (NDS), Dementia Action Alliance (DAA), National Audit for Dementia (NAD), National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE).
Definitions

table_items.text: Do not attempt cardio pulmonary resuscitation
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence

data.text: Roles and responsibilities

Dementia Strategy/Steering Group are responsible for the implementation of the Trusts Dementia Strategy ensuring that any concerns relating to compliance with relevant CQC Fundamental Standards are acted upon and escalated to the Safe Guarding Board.
Chief Executive as Accountable Officer is responsible for the safety and care quality provided by the Trust.

Director of Nursing/Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessments (where appropriate) are available to ensure all medical and non-medical staff ( doctors, nurses, midwives and allied health care professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Director of Nursing at Southend Hospital is the Safeguarding Lead for MSE which encompasses Dementia.
Associate Director of Safeguarding is the Lead for Dementia across MSE responsible for the strategic and corporate direction including professional advice on matters relating to Dementia Care.

Consultant Clinical Lead is responsible for leading on Dementia is complied with – Championing dementia care within the Organisation and provide expert medical advice and ensuring relevant information is disseminated.

Dementia and Delirium /Admiral Nurse providing specialist nursing assessment, evidence based intervention, advice and support to staff caring for patients with dementia and support to relatives or carers. Support the dementia service lead in delivering the contents of the dementia policy ensuring relevant information is disseminated

Associate Directors of Nursing/ Matrons/Heads of Departments/Service Managers/Department Managers are responsible for the implementation of this policy across their divisions and facilitate/support the Dementia and Delirium/Admiral Nurse ensuring staff receive the appropriate training to enable them to work within the principles of this policy. This includes: Identifying training needs and ensuring staff attend training and that staff in their divisions are compliant with training.

Clinical Specialist Nurses/Lead Nurses responsible for providing specialist advice to staff–working collaboratively with Dementia and Delirium/Admiral Nurse in meeting complex needs of patients with dementia.

Learning Disability Nurse Specialist will work collaboratively with the Dementia and Delirium./Admiral Nurse supporting ward staff to meet the complex needs of Patients with a Learning Disability and dementia during inpatient stay.

Nursing Staff have a responsibility to ensure patients receive evidence based care at a high standard. Patients with dementia are usually dependant on staff having the skills and knowledge to meet their needs effectively and ensure the patient's experience is less stressful and their inpatient stay is no longer than necessary. The nursing staff should also, therefore adhere to, implement and assist in the delivery of this policy and the associated clinical procedures. They must identify any restrictions/risks in implementing the policy or its associated procedures as well as identify personal limitations. They are also responsible for addressing educational needs to ensure optimal therapy is delivered to maximise patient's comfort – completing mandatory training in relation to Dementia according to their role.
Dementia screening

It is essential that dementia is diagnosed as early as possible in the disease process to enable people access to the appropriate care, support and treatment available, including support to plan for the future i.e. making an advanced decision and appointing a Lasting Power of Attorney (DAA, NDS, NICE).
Individual organisations are monitored by NHS England and compared to the national target of 66.7% of estimated dementia cases being diagnosed (NHS digital, 2017).

On admission it should be established whether a patient has a known diagnosis and if so, the date diagnosed and the type of dementia must be documented. An Alert should then be added to the patients' Medical Records (site-specific systems) by system manage person request from Clinical Staff

In the presence of a joint diagnosis of Learning disabilities and dementia a referral to Learning Disability Nurse Specialist and Dementia and Delirium/Admiral Nurse should be made for advice and support.

The nursing and medical staff are responsible for ensuring the Dementia screening tool (Find, Assess, Investigate & Refer; Appendix 1) is completed for all emergency admissions for patients aged  and over. (Please refer to site specific screening tool)
Diagnosis
A diagnosis of dementia should only be made when all other reversible causes of cognitive impairment have been excluded.
5.6.2 Comprehensive physical examination must be completed and appropriate investigations carried out:
Complete dementia blood screen (B12, Folate, TSH and other tests, if relevant, for example Syphilis serology);
Computed Tomography (CT scan) head.

5.6.3 A comprehensive biographical profile must be completed by thorough discussion with the patient and a relative, carer or someone who knows the patient well confirming a chronic history of cognitive decline.
Complete Mini-Ace Assessment tool (Appendix 2)
Exclude undiagnosed or untreated depression.  Complete Geriatric Depression Scale (Appendix 3) - if depression is suspected then consider treatment and referral to mental health team.

Exclude undiagnosed, untreated or resolving delirium. Complete Confusion Assessment Method (used in Intensive Care Units on each site)  (Appendix 4) or the 4AT (Appendix 5) used in clinical areas on each site.
5.6.4 If it is clinically necessary to make a diagnosis of dementia as an in-patient, the Consultant in charge and/or team is responsible for ensuring the following referrals (NDS, NAD, DAA, NICE):
A referral to the Dementia Specialist to ensure that patients and their relatives receive written and verbal information and support as an in-patient.

A referral on discharge to the appropriate Community Service to ensure the patient is assessed for treatment and the patient and their relative/carer is provided with on-going support and assessment as well as information on support options local to their area.
Include new diagnosis and onward referral in Hospital Discharge Letter to GP
Assessment and Care Planning
It is essential that the following information is collated and assessments are completed to ensure individualised care plans for patients with dementia.
Collateral History
Establish functional and cognitive baseline prior to admission which may include the following:
Medical – Falls, Pain, Pressure Ulcers, Polypharmacy, Nutrition;
Mental Health – delirium, dementia, delirium on the background of dementia, depression, concerns or fears;
Functional capacity - mobility ADLs, continence, sensory (vision/hearing);
Social.
‘This Is Me'

To enable effective care planning and to provide appropriate occupation and stimulation (meaningful activities) for people with dementia, it is essential that a life history is obtained. This should be completed using the ‘This Is Me' document, with the patient and their relative/carer where ever possible. This document supports hospital staff to provide person centred approach to care which may reduce agitation/aggression and potentially reduce their length of stay. The ‘This Is Me' documentation should accompany the patient when discharged from hospital. (Appendix 6)
Pain Assessment and the Abbey Pain Scale

5.10.1 Patients with dementia may express their pain in ways that are different from patients without dementia. Research has highlighted that people with dementia are at higher risk of experiencing unmanaged pain (Alzheimer's Society, 2019). It is often necessary to prescribe analgesia regularly rather than ‘as required'.
5.10.2 Pain should be assessed using the Abbey pain assessment tool at leasttimes daily and reassessed following any intervention for pain.(Appendix 8)
End of Life Care
5.11.1 As dementia advances it is important that all professionals consider whether the person may be reaching the end stages of the disease and plan future care appropriately.
5.11.2 This is likely to require a Mental Capacity Assessment and Best Interests decision (see MCA Policy).
5.11.3 Discussions may include the following:
DNACPR;
TEP;
PeACE document;
Accessing information of existing ACP.
5.11.4 Referrals should be made to Dementia and Delirium Nurse/Admiral Nurse and Palliative care team for advice and support, as well as accessing Site specific policies for further information.
Nutritional Assessment:

5.12.1 As dementia progresses, there may be changes in a person's eating habits and their ability to eat independently. There may be changes to taste, the ability to swallow or appetite (increase or decrease). Various factors can also hinder oral intake including constipation, mouth problems and poor oral hygiene. Finger foods are good way of prolonging independent eating and can be used if the patient is unable to sit still for long periods of time. Access to snacks and adapted crockery and cutlery can also support the patient with their nutritional intake.
5.12.2 If there are concerns about a patient's nutritional intake, refer to the Dietetic department, when indicated in line with the Trust Acute Nutrition policy.
Inpatient bed moves:

Patients with dementia are likely to experience increased disorientation each time they encounter an unfamiliar environment. Patients with dementia must not be moved within the ward or between wards unless it is clinically indicated between 2000-0800 hours.
Decision making

5.14.1 All patients with dementia should be presumed to have capacity unless proven otherwise. All decisions about their care and treatment and consent must be gained lawfully. All clinicians must adhere to the Consent to Treatment policy.

5.14.2 If there is sufficient evidence to suggest that the patient may lack capacity to make a particular decision, clinicians must complete a mental capacity assessment. All clinicians must understand and adhere to the Mental Capacity Act (2005) and the Trust Mental Capacity Act policy.
5.14.3 The patient must remain at the centre of decision making even if it is determined that he/she does not have the capacity to make a particular decision.
5.14.4 The Dementia and Delirium/Admiral Nurse are available to provide support and advice regarding all best interests decisions made on behalf of patients with dementia if required.
Behavioural and Psychological Symptoms of Dementia

5.15.1 A significant number of people will develop what are known as "behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia". These may include increased agitation, depressive symptoms, anxiety, wandering, aggression or sometimes hallucinations (NHS, 2017). This can be distressing as well as presenting a challenge to staff delivering care.

5.15.2 In many cases behavioural and psychological symptoms can be prevented and managed without resorting to antipsychotic drugs. The key to achieving this is to follow the principles of good person-centred care. Referral to Dementia and Delirium Nurse/Admiral Nurse for support and advice, and a mental health opinion should be sought where appropriate.
5.15.3 The key points of person-centred care are:
Treating the person with dignity and respect;
Understanding their history, lifestyle, culture and preferences, including their likes, dislikes, hobbies and interests;
Looking at situations from the point of view of the person with dementia;
Providing opportunities for the person to have conversations and relationships with other people;
Ensuring the person has the chance to try new things or take part in activities they enjoy.

5.15.4 NICE guidance (2019) recommends that before starting non-pharmacological or pharmacological treatment for distress in people living with dementia, possible reasons for their distress should be explored and environmental causes should be addressed.
5.15.5 It is therefore important that staff ensure the patient is not experiencing any of the following:
Pain;
Thirst;
Hunger;
Dry/sore mouth;
Constipation;
Boredom;
Lack of exercise;
Too hot/cold;
Over-stimulation;

5.15.6 People with dementia have the same needs as everyone else, including comfort, social interaction, stimulation, emotional wellbeing, spiritual needs and being free from pain. However, people with dementia may be unable to recognise their needs, know how to meet them, or communicate what they need to others. Ensure the patient is supported to communicate his/her feelings. It is common for all people to become frustrated and sometimes aggressive if they feel ignored. The VERA framework offers a means of interpreting communication and responding appropriately (see references for link)

5.15.7 Family, carers and the person with dementia (where possible) should always be involved in developing a care plan based on person-centred care. All families or carers should be offered open visiting/concessionary parking and where applicable refer to Carers First and discuss the Carers Passport.

5.15.8 It is essential that all behaviour is documented on the site specific Activity/ Behaviour Chart. The purpose of this is so themes can be examined and ‘triggers' which might precipitate behaviour and effective strategies can be identified.

5.15.9 Where patients are requiring increased levels of support or observation staff must complete the site specific assessment tool and refer to Local Policy. A Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards application should be considered if the person lacks the mental capacity to consent.

5.15.10 In all instances where patients with dementia are declining or refusing any aspect of care or treatment a mental capacity assessment should be considered and a referral must be made to the Dementia and Delirium Nurse/Admiral Nurse. If refusal relates to medication a decision should be made to consider Covert medication following a best interest process
5.15.11If it is suspected that a person may have a delirium super-imposed on dementia,
refer to the local guidelines/policies on Delirium Management.
Use of Sedation

5.16.1The use of sedatives must only be considered when non-pharmacological interventions have been attempted. The clinical rationale for using sedation/antipsychotic medication must be documented in the medical notes. If the patient is unable to consent to medication a mental capacity assessment should be completed (Mental Capacity Act, 2005).

5.16.1 The side-effects of sedation and antipsychotics can be very harmful and can diminish quality of life. Side effects include excessive drowsiness, dizziness and unsteadiness, which can lead to increased falls and injuries, as well as Parkinsonism (tremors and rigidity), body restlessness, reduced well-being, social withdrawal and accelerated cognitive decline.
5.16.2 Medication may be indicated in the following situations:
In order to carry out essential investigations/treatment or prevent removal of life saving equipment;
To calm patients who are exhibiting extreme behaviour which is likely to endanger themselves and others e.g. physical assault of other patients or staff;
To relieve distress in a patient who is highly agitated or hallucinating;
Only when all other remedies have been attempted and as a last resort.

5.16.3 It is essential to be aware that people with Vascular Dementia, Alzheimer's disease or mixed Dementia have an increased risk of cerebrovascular adverse events and death when given anti-psychotic medication.

5.16.4 Be aware that for people with dementia with Lewy bodies or Parkinson's disease dementia, antipsychotics can worsen the motor features of the condition, and in some cases cause severe antipsychotic sensitivity reactions (NICE, 2019). Anti- psychotics are contra-indicated for people with Lewy Body dementia; they have a particular sensitivity to anti -psychotic medication which can lead to profound adverse events and death.
5.16.5 Consider the following when prescribing medication:
Monotherapy;
Prescribe initial ‘stat' dose and then reassess;
Prescribe regularly;
Start with a low dose and titrate;
Avoid ‘PRN' (as required) prescriptions;
Review regularly and discontinue as soon as possible.

5.16.6 Where a patient repeatedly expresses a wish to leave the clinical areas, either verbally or by physically trying to leave the clinical area, or sedation is being used to prevent this, these actions would amount to deprivation of liberty. Clinicians should refer to Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards policy.
5.16.7 All those involved in prescribing and administering sedation to a patient with dementia must be familiar with the following:
Mental Health Act 1983;
Requirements of the relevant articles of the European Convention on Human Rights;
Mental Capacity Act (2005) and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (2009);
Consent to Treatment Policy;
Violence and Aggression Policy;
Advocacy services.

5.16.8 Behaviour/Activity Charts must be used to review all patients who are presenting with behaviour which could be perceived as challenging or patients who are becoming very withdrawn and disengaging. This will enable staff to review:
Trigger factors;
What happened during the incident;
Staff response to the incident including interventions used;
What was the outcome including the patients response;
Root cause analysis (RCA) to be completed if the incident has an unfavourable outcome.
Incident reporting

All incidents of chemical or physical restraint should be reported as a clinical incident via the Organisations Incident Reporting Tool, investigation and learning from these incidents are shared across the organisation.

All episodes of violence should reported as a clinical incident via the Organisations Incident Reporting Tool in line with the Trust Incident Reporting Policy. A referral to the Adult Safeguarding and Dementia and Delirium Nurse /Admiral Nurse may be considered in order to support staff to facilitate an assessment of the patient's needs.

A risk event form via the Organisations Incident Reporting Tool must be completed when this policy has not been followed and a patient has experienced harm or disadvantage as a result. This may require a safeguarding alert (please refer to Adult Safeguarding policy).
Training requirements

Education, training and skills acquisition are a hallmark of good dementia care. The Dementia Training Standards Framework is structured in three tiers to reflect the scope of Health Education England's (HEE, 2018) principal mandate requirements and this Framework is used throughout MSE.
Tier 1: dementia awareness raising, in terms of knowledge, skills and attributes for all those working in health and care settings.
Tier : knowledge, skills and attitudes for roles that have regular contact with people living with dementia.
Tier 3: enhancing the knowledge, skills and attitudes for key staff (experts) working with people living with dementia designed to support them to play leadership roles.

It is the responsibility all staff, paid, voluntary and contracted to completed the agreed level of training and the responsibility of service leads to ensure all staff are up to date and complaint with this training.
Monitoring and audit

data.text: Approval and implementation

This policy will be approved by the MSE Safeguarding Group which is the group with the authority to approve safeguarding policies. The policy will be forwarded to the Document Control Team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Safeguarding Group which is the group of the approved policy document when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets. This revised policy will be made available to staff on the Trust's intranet site and website.
All new staff will be made aware of the policy during staff induction training.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals (Refer to appendix 1)

Appendix 5: Confusion Assessment Method CAM

table_items.text: Acute onset and fluctuating course? (Acute change in mental status from baseline, fluctuating behaviour through the day)
Inattention? (Difficulty focusing attention, easily distracted, difficulty keeping track of what is being said)
Disorganised thinking? (disorganized or incoherent thinking, rambling or irrelevant conversation, unclear or illogical flow of ideas)
Altered level of consciousness? (This feature is shown by any answer other than “alert”, including: hyper-alert, lethargic, stupor, or coma)
The diagnosis of Delirium by CAM requires the presence of features 1 and 2 AND EITHER 3 or 4

data.text: Reference: Inouye SK, Van Dyck CH, Alessi CA, Balkin S, Siegal AP, Horwitz RI (1990)
Clarifying confusion: the Confusion Assessment Method.  Annals of Internal Medicine 113: 941-8
